title: How is impact created from data?
displayTitle: How is impact created from data?

_items.text: Creating products that collect and use data

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

All aspects are equally important but are often imbalanced. It is increasingly easy to collect vast swathes of data which can then go unused. Opportunities to innovate with existing data are often missed because it is not shared with the people who need it.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

All aspects are equally important but are often imbalanced. It is increasingly easy to collect vast swathes of data which can then go unused. Opportunities to innovate with existing data are often missed because it is not shared with the people who need it.

title: Enabling our superpower
body: In addition to making use of the catalog to discover data, what else should you do?

_items.text: List your datasets in the catalog
Download all the data from the catalog to build your own data lake
Sell data from the catalog to other clients

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

To maximise the potential value of data, we must all play our part in building our data ecosystem. This means being open with the data we each hold and clear on how others can obtain access to it. Listing data in the catalog doesn’t mean all WPP staff have unlimited access: agencies will be able to define who has access and whether it’s free, paid or restricted. Contributing data listings to the catalog not only helps others (including yourselves) discover data but also helps WPP identify data gaps and routes to fill these where necessary.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

To maximise the potential value of data, we must all play our part in building our data ecosystem. This means being open with the data we each hold and clear on how others can obtain access to it. Listing data in the catalog doesn’t mean all WPP staff have unlimited access: agencies will be able to define who has access and whether it’s free, paid or restricted. Contributing data listings to the catalog not only helps others (including yourselves) discover data but also helps WPP identify data gaps and routes to fill these where necessary.

title: Case studies: organisations being more open and trusted with data
displayTitle: Case studies: organisations being more open and trusted with data
mobileInstruction: Click '+' to explore each case study

_items.title: Increasing online sales
_items.body:
Competing for sales in the online market is tough. There are now a large number of channels that can be used to reach potential customers including dynamic paid search, story campaigns and even direct-buy buttons that can be embedded by review websites, on blogs, and in other social media.

These all rely on real-time product data including prices and (increasingly) availability. We are seeing retailers being increasingly open with their product data, helping it reach new channels, enabling them to be more visible and competitive in the marketplace.

_items.title: Building a platform for data flows
_items.body: Amazon realised early that parts of the business that collected data and held it in silos could prevent it from realising the most value from data. Amazon also realised that it should design these services to also be available externally, enabling organisations and individuals to use the data to innovate. Amazon now provides the data infrastructure for hundreds of companies who use it to connect to their markets and grow their businesses.
_items.strapline: Building a platform for data flows

_items.title: Winning awards for ethical data practices
_items.body:
In 2019, Co-op was awarded the DatalQ Award for Best Data Ethics and Privacy Programme.

In an era where data is increasingly crucial to commercial success and customers are growing more aware of how data about them is used, this award recognises Co-op colleagues’ commitment to being trusted with the data about its members, customers, and communities, which helps ensure that the business makes informed and ethical decisions that support its values.

Co-op, which offers a diverse range of products and services, used the Open Data Institute’s Data Ethics Canvas to empower teams and help them identify and manage ethical issues when using data, while building data literacy.
_items.strapline: Winning awards for ethical data practices

title: Using data to lead creative transformation at WPP
body: To deliver creative transformation through data, we have a four-strand approach.
instruction: Click '+' to find out more about each strand

_items.title: Open
_items.body: We have built the WPP OPEN Data Catalog for our data community to access an index of data available across WPP and to share non-sensitive data. The catalog has already increased collaboration between our data talent in our creative, media and digital agencies.

_items.title: Trusted
_items.body: Creative transformation must be done in a way that maintains and boosts brand reputation and trust. With fears over AI and data being used to monitor, track and influence people we have run AI ethics workshops with 10 of our agencies and are creating guidelines and principles to be used alongside our AI Code of Conduct. These guidelines and principles will be rolled out to agencies in 2020, with the goal to embed them in everyday activities.

_items.title: Future-proofed
_items.body: To help everyone get creative through data, we will provide data literacy programmes for everyone. In addition to these modules, our AI Academy upskilled 2,500 data scientists in 2020 and the same again in 2021. Our Demystify AI programme will help upskill 25,000 of our colleagues in AI basics.

_items.title: Creatively inspiring
_items.body: We are building a cross-agency, cross-market, multi-discipline data and AI community. This group fuels our creativity through code sharing, blogs, and challenges that give us space to think about questions laterally and to tackle client problems; and helps ensure we don’t duplicate work.

title: Common barriers to achieving impact from data
displayTitle: Common barriers to achieving impact from data
body: Which of the following are common barriers to achieving impact from data?

_items.text: A lack of willingness to share data with others
No suitable technology to make use of data

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

Cultural resistance and fear of data misuse are the most common barriers to achieving impact from data; technology and data are never in short supply. The following section introduces the Open Data Institutes theory of change which looks at what needs to be done to overcome these barriers.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

Cultural resistance and fear of data misuse are the most common barriers to achieving impact from data; technology and data are never in short supply. The following section introduces the Open Data Institutes theory of change which looks at what needs to be done to overcome these barriers.

title: Where data sits in our landscape
displayTitle: Where data sits in our landscape
body:
We want data to motivate, inspire and to grow our creativity to help deliver high-quality products for our clients. Our clients pay for high-quality data outputs, not for huge data lakes which become too big and cumbersome to maintain.

“Through 2022, over 80% of data lake projects will fail to deliver value. Finding, inventorying and curating data will prove to be the biggest inhibitor to analytics and data science success.” - Gartner, September 2019

WPP is not in the business of buying, collecting and storing huge swathes of irrelevant data, especially when a lot of data is already available.

“Data increases in value the more it is connected” - ODI 2017

We want to enable our community to discover new sources of high-quality data – both internally and externally – we created the WPP OPEN Data catalog. The catalog provides an index of data available across WPP and enables our community to share non-sensitive data. The catalog has already increased collaboration between our data talent across our creative, media and digital agencies.

title: The data landscape
body:
Data is moving from being scarce and difficult to process to being abundant and easy to use.

However, to realise the full benefits that data can bring, businesses must understand the ‘data landscape’.

This module introduces:

  • Where data sits in our landscape
  • How value is created from data
  • Common barriers that prevent the full value of data being realised
  • The advantages of being more open and trusted with data
  • How WPP is using data to lead creative transformation

_graphic.attribution: Adapted from the Open Data Institute's theory of change [CC-BY-SA]

title: Where next?
body:
To help everyone discover more about how WPP is using data, there are three additional modules available, each designed to help you discover more on each strand:

Getting value from data: Creative inspiration and more…

Find out more about how data can be collected, shared and used not just for creative inspiration but also to help realise other benefits.

Being trusted with data

We believe that clients should be able to rely on our data expertise to deliver creative transformation because they trust us to be responsible with data; to hold ourselves accountable for the data-driven decisions we are making; and to do our best to protect our clients. This module looks at what mechanisms need to be in place to ensure we are trusted to be responsible with data.

Working with data

We know data is imperfect and it’s only as good as the questions you ask of it – good design is imperative. This module introduces some of the key aspects involved in working with data that help us ensure data is well managed and can be used to generate transformative results.

title: Common barriers (1): Hoarding data
body:
One of the biggest challenges to realising the full value of data is the lack of cultural willingness to share data. The ODI calls this scenario ‘the oil field’.

The oil field is a scenario where: owning data; having as much data as possible in one place; trying to know everything about everyone and then maintaining the inevitable degradation of these datasets – is killing the return on investment (and the fun!) when working with  data, and it’s not the only way!

Such approaches lead to a closed (or walled garden) environment which can greatly reduce innovation capabilities.

To overcome this barrier, organisations should support an open culture as much as possible. During challenging times it is especially important to realise the benefits of working with others, sharing insights and innovating together.

Building a data catalog that we can all use helps ensure variety is our data superpower. It also helps to prevent hoarding and the inevitable associated degradation of data.

title: Data variety is our superpower
body:
Data is both a source of inspiration and a material used in the development of creative products. We can use data to help shape and refine what we create, reach new markets, drive engagement and deliver emotional experiences that connect consumers to our brands.

This superpower can only be activated when the right data is collected and made available to those who need it.

At WPP we want our data talent to spend as much time as possible using data creatively, not having to find and obtain access to data. This is why we have created the WPP Open Data catalog. The catalog will enable everyone to list, discover and explore relevant data that is available from the community as well as external sources.

Of course, we have access to all the usual datasets; audience data, client data, brand data, transactional data, market data, campaign data, creative and media data and operational data.

title: Creating impact with data
body:
Value is created when we collect, manage and share data in ways that support creative transformation.

For example, recently we have seen how data can be used to: deliver £14m of sales for a large supermarket chain; demonstrate how nearly all modern music has roots in Tennessee; and create dynamic and unique brand experiences for music venues. You can find out more about these and other case studies in the next module.

Clients should be able to rely on our data expertise to deliver creative transformation because they trust us: to be responsible with data; to hold ourselves accountable for the data-driven decisions we are making; and to do our best to protect our clients.

To realise the value of data we need to develop the culture, capabilities and infrastructure that help ensure data is not siloed, and enable it to be used alongside other data.

title: Common barriers (2): Fearing data
body:
If data is unused and unloved, it will degrade and could potentially lead to security risks, reputational and brand damage. The ODI calls this scenario ‘the wasteland’.

The wasteland is most prevalent in situations where unaddressed fears arising from legitimate concerns – such as who has access to data and how it might be used – prevent any benefits being realised.

The ODI recommends putting in place practices that ensure the way data is collected and used is trustworthy and just.

To help address these fears WPP Open is developing a set of Data Ethics Principles and Guidelines that will be rolled out in each agency to ensure there is equity around who accesses, uses and benefits from data.

_graphic.attribution: The Open Data Institute [CC-BY-SA]
